articles.headline: A World Unprepared, Again, for Rising Interest Rates
articles.snippet: The pullout of capital from emerging markets eerily resembles the financial wave that emerged from Asia and swept across the globe in the late 1990s.
articles.abstract: The pullout of capital from emerging markets eerily resembles the financial wave that emerged from Asia and swept across the globe in the late 1990s.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — I was living in São Paulo in 1997 when, out of the blue, an investment banker I knew in London called to ask about Brazilian cocktails. He didn’t want one. He needed a name for a potential economic crisis, in the vein of Mexico’s Tequila affair in 1994 and Thailand’s Tom Yum Kung debacle, which was unfolding at the time.

articles.headline: Graco Recalls Car Seats Over Faulty Buckle
articles.snippet: Federal safety regulators pushed the company to expand the recall as parents complained that they had to cut the straps to remove their children.
articles.abstract: Federal safety regulators pushed the company to expand the recall as parents complained that they had to cut the straps to remove their children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Graco Children’s Products is recalling almost 3.8 million car seats because faulty buckles can make it hard to free the child in an emergency, the company said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: U.S. Targets Buyers of China-Bound Luxury Cars
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors in six states have filed actions against businesses that buy luxury cars at domestic dealerships and then send them to China.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors in six states have filed actions against businesses that buy luxury cars at domestic dealerships and then send them to China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael A. Downs, a businessman in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., says he is simply looking to profit from the growing demand in China for cars from the likes of Mercedes, BMW and Range Rover.

articles.headline: Rival Industries Sweet-Talk the Public
articles.snippet: Court documents show that the corn refinery and sugar industries spent millions to enlist academics and lobbying groups to support a secret public relations war over the market for sweeteners.
articles.abstract: Court documents show that the corn refinery and sugar industries spent millions to enlist academics and lobbying groups to support a secret public relations war over the market for sweeteners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The corn refinery and sugar industries, bitter rivals in the manufacture of billions of dollars’ worth of sweeteners for sodas and other high-calorie foods, covertly funded dueling nonprofit groups in Washington in a multiyear effort to grab market share, while also stoking fears among consumers about possible health risks, court records made public in a federal lawsuit between the two parties show.

articles.headline: Cuba’s Reward for the Dutiful: Gated Housing
articles.snippet: With new apartments for families tied to the military and the interior ministry, President Raúl Castro is redoubling efforts to elevate the faithful and maintain their loyalty.
articles.abstract: With new apartments for families tied to the military and the interior ministry, President Raúl Castro is redoubling efforts to elevate the faithful and maintain their loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — In the splendid neighborhoods of this dilapidated city, old mansions are being upgraded with imported tile. Businessmen go out for sushi and drive home in plush Audis. Now, hoping to keep up, the government is erecting something special for its own: a housing development called Project Granma, featuring hundreds of comfortable apartments in a gated complex set to have its own movie theater and schools.

articles.headline: Liquid-Cooled Supercomputers, to Trim the Power Bill
articles.snippet: Looking to reduce energy bills and environmental strains, operators of supercomputers are immersing them in cooling liquids.
articles.abstract: Looking to reduce energy bills and environmental strains, operators of supercomputers are immersing them in cooling liquids.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Dropping a home computer into a vat of liquid would wreck it.

articles.headline: In Governors’ Races This Year, Lessons for 2016
articles.snippet: Closely watched elections are approaching in Ohio, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, where white working-class voters were once solidly Democratic but are now up for grabs.
articles.abstract: Closely watched elections are approaching in Ohio, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, where white working-class voters were once solidly Democratic but are now up for grabs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Three years after stripping public employee unions of the right to collectively bargain, Gov. Scott Walker began this election year by introducing workers who had found jobs since he took office. A dozen stood with him in the State Capitol, dressed for the workplace: a nursing assistant, an accountant, a maintenance technician at Milwaukee Valve.

articles.headline: Toyota Recalls Newest Priuses Over Software
articles.snippet: The Japanese carmaker said it was recalling all 1.9 million latest-generation Prius cars sold worldwide because of a defect in the vehicle’s hybrid system.
articles.abstract: The Japanese carmaker said it was recalling all 1.9 million latest-generation Prius cars sold worldwide because of a defect in the vehicle’s hybrid system.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toyota Motor is recalling all of the 1.9 million newest-generation Prius vehicles it has sold worldwide because of a programming error that could cause their gas-electric hybrid systems to shut down, the automaker said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Jaclyn Trop
